text.text_translated:
Sam squinted against the sun. He saw the dust trail raised by the car on its way up to the Big House.  
The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies. They did not care that this was their owner's first visit in ten months.  
Sam waited. Mr Carter did not come out here unless he had to, which was fine for Sam.  
The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he would keep his job.  
Mr Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt came together like shapes on a map.  
His skin was already turning red in the June sun. Otherwise, he had the indoor tan of a man who made money while other people did the work.

feedback.feedback: This is an excellent simplification that passes all priority checks. Factual integrity is perfectly maintained, and the high MeaningBERT (0.92) and BERTScore (0.95) metrics confirm that the core meaning and key details were successfully preserved. The output correctly achieves the target B1 CEFR level. The simplification strategy was very effective, particularly in breaking down the first long sentence into two clearer, more manageable sentences. The vocabulary choices were strong, for example, replacing 'ruddy' with 'red' and 'atlas' with 'map'. For future improvement, consider simplifying the C1-level word 'trail' to an alternative like 'line of dust', but this is a minor point in an otherwise outstanding submission.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Sam squinted against the sun. He saw the dust trail raised by the car on its way up to the Big House.  
The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies. They did not care that this was their owner's first visit in ten months.  
Sam waited. Mr Carter did not come out here unless he had to, which was fine for Sam.  
The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he would keep his job.  
Mr Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt came together like shapes on a map.  
His skin was already turning red in the June sun. Otherwise, he had the indoor tan of a man who made money while other people did the work.
